comment._content: That is a lovely goose - it's like a swan and a goose!

comment.author: 8014448@N07
comment._content:
That is an unusual bird. Too bad that the only other reference I ever heard of the gannet in my life came from Monty Python's Flying Circus' audio skits.

'I don't like the gannet - they wet their nests!' complains the absurd shopper, who is looking for a Book of Britih Birds.

'All right!!' John Cleese, as the book shop clerk, cries, and tears it out.
'There you are sir!'

'I can't buy that. It's torn!'

comment.author: 57845960@N00
comment._content: I like this photograph a lot, and used it to create a drawing: www.flickr.com/photos/ninaartist/4149559690/

comment.author: 47336118@N02
comment._content: Young gannets were an important food in some parts of the Hebrides, especially St. Kilda. They are still eaten in Lewis. (Fishy, oily  chicken, in case you were wondering!)

comment.author: 48809099@N02
comment._content: I think the young gannets are called Googa's and are still highly prized.
